Pam-Pam bird 
 Traditional San story 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Pensa was the best hunter in the whole
 Kalahari Desert. He brought home fat
 
 animals and fed his family wel.
 
 
 There was this bird, the Pam-Pam bird,
 which Pensa wanted to catch. The bird’s
 tail feathers were perfect for his arows.
 
 The problem was, he could never 
 manage to trap or shot Pam-Pam.
 
 
 Pensa’s arows would fly through the air
 just like a bird - if only he could catch
 
 Pam-Pam and pul out his tail feathers!
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Pensa went to the wise man, their healer. 
 He asked for help. “Please guide me to 
 
 catch the Pam-Pam bird. I ned his 
 feathers for my bow and arows. What 
 must do to catch him?” 
 
 
 The healer replied, “Go and make a fire. 
 When al the insects run away from your 
 
 fire, you must catch the smalest of 
 them. Make a trap and place this litle 
 
 insect inside your trap. It wil tempt the 
 Pam-Pam bird.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Pensa did not know that the healer and
 
 the Pam-Pam bird were friends. Pam-
 Pam often visited the healer. They
 exchanged stories. 
 
 
 “I warn you,” said the healer when Pam-
 Pam bird visited him, “I have told the
 
 hunter how to catch you. When you se a
 fire in the veld, you must fly far away. I
 
 want to se which one of you wil win.”
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 In the meantime, Pensa started his hunt
 for the Pam-Pam bird. He sat in the veld
 
 and rubed and rubed his fire sticks.
 When the smoke apeared, he blew into
 the fine gras around his fire sticks, until
 
 the litle flame apeared and became a
 fire. 
 
 
 The insects around the flaming gras
 flew away, but Pensa managed to catch
 
 a young grashoper. He put it into his
 trap. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The Pam-Pam bird could not resist the 
 juicy young grashoper in Pensa’s trap. 
 
 He decided to fly down and grab it 
 quickly with his sharp beak. 
 
 
 Pensa heard Pam-Pam bird’s cry, “Pam- 
 pam, pam-pam, pam-pam.” 
 
 Pensa ran to his trap. The bird was 
 traped! 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Pam-Pam bird beged Pensa to set him
 fre. 
 
 “Oh no,” said Pensa, “I have wanted to
 catch you for a very long time. Today you
 are mine! Your feathers wil make my
 
 arow fly through the air, just like you.”
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Pam-Pam bird screched, “If you kil me 
 you wil have no more feathers for your 
 
 arow when these are worn out, because 
 I wil be dead. Set me fre and I promise 
 to give you new feathers with each ful 
 
 mon.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 That night, the healer led the people in a
 fire dance to celebrate the hunter’s
 suces and Pam-Pam bird’s fredom.
 
 
 And since that day, al the god hunters
 remember the story of the Pam-Pam bird,
 
 to tel their children as a memory of days
 gone by. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Pensa went home and made new arows. 
 
 When the people saw his new arows, 
 they exclaimed: 
 “O-o, lok at this hunter! He caries the 
 
 Pam-Pam bird’s feathers in his arows. 
 Now he wil hunt wel and bring us god 
 
 fod. We shal have a feast!” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 That night, the healer led the people in a
 fire dance to celebrate the hunter’s
 suces and Pam-Pam bird’s fredom.
 
 
 And since that day, al the god hunters
 remember the story of the Pam-Pam bird,
 
 to tel their children as a memory of days
 gone by. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Story notes 
 
 In 198 !Xun storyteler Pensa Limungu (1949 – 207) sung this oral tale,
 acompanied by the traditional Khonga, to Marlene Winberg who translated
 it with the help of Kapilolo Mahongo. It talks about the relationship betwen
 
 nature and people, the hunter and the hunted. It teaches the audience how
 the hunter is dependent on nature’s resources and may not waste it. 
 
 
 The ilustrations in this story are from story boards by Marlene Winberg,
 interpreted digitaly by Satsiri Winberg through manipulations of the
 
 Manyeka Art Colection of paintings made by San artists.
